titleInfo.title: Fred C. Matthews, Jr. oral history interview

mods.abstract: Matthews discusses the movement of farmers to Baton Rouge in the 1920s, and African American businesses in the South Baton Rouge community. Matthews mainly recalls his career at Standard Oil and advancements in oil refining techniques. He describes race relations at Exxon over the years, and the upward mobility of African Americans within the company after the Civil Rights Act. He speculates on the rise and fall of African American-owned businesses in Baton Rouge.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0701. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Rudolph Henry, Michael Goods, Nedra Carter, and Khary Carrell.

Fred Matthews was born in West Feliciana Parish, La., on February 1, 1906. Matthews worked at the Standard Oil (Esso) Refinery, now Exxon/Mobil, for nearly forty years. He was the highest ranking and highest paid African American there for many years. Matthews was married and had three children. He worked in publicity for Baptist churches for twenty-five years and was a World War II veteran. Matthews passed away in 2002 at age 95.
